title: (x) "The Problem of the Media" Robert McChesney book - Swift {Héctor}
content:
These are scans from a book called _The Problem of the Media_, by Robert McChesney, published 2004. I tried Identifont to no avail. It seems very familiar but I can't put my finger on it. I don't know if it has small caps, but they aren't used in the book. OsFs are, but they are a little darker than the rest of the text, which I thought was strange. Anyway, here goes...   
   
 ![McChesney1](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018043125im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/69958.jpg)   
   
 ![McChesney2](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018043125im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/69959.jpg)   
   
 ![McChesney3](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018043125im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/69960.jpg)   
   
It isn't as noticeable on screen, but in the actual physical book the figures appear much darker than everything else, almost as if it's a bold weight. My wife is trying to go to sleep and is not well pleased with my noise-making, so good night.
author: Isaac

comments.content:
This is Swift, and officially my third type ID.   
   
 [http://www.identifont.com/show?9XF](http://web.archive.org/web/20131018043125/http:/www.identifont.com/show?9XF)

Thanks, and congrats on that third ID.   
   
I was thinking Dutch, didn't want to assume. Any thought on why the figures are so dark?

I think they used Swift Regular Small Caps for figures, the rest of text being Swift Light.   
   
Regular Small Caps seems to be the only Swift with OSF.
